home.heroSubtitle: Join a world-class department where innovation meets excellence. Discover cutting-edge research, transformative education, and global impact.
home.welcomeIntro: We are the Computer Science Division at Stellenbosch University—a place where teaching and research go hand in hand.
home.welcomeHistory1: The Department of Computer Science was founded in 1972. We have now merged with Mathematics and Applied Mathematics to form the Computer Science Division in the Department of Mathematical Sciences.
home.welcomeHistory2: We currently have 11 full members of academic staff whose research activities span a range of subject areas, including Automata Theory, Broadband and Mobile Networks, Software Engineering, Program Testing and Verification, Robotics, Natural Language Processing, and Machine Learning.
home.worldClassResearchSub: Pioneering discoveries that shape the future of technology and society
home.learnFromLeadersSub: Our distinguished faculty includes leading researchers, award-winning educators, and industry pioneers who are shaping the future of computer science.
home.readySub: Join our community of innovators, researchers, and future leaders in computer science
home.aiDesc: Advanced machine learning, deep learning, and neural network research.
home.roboticsDesc: Cutting-edge robotics, autonomous systems, and human-robot interaction.
home.networksDesc: Distributed systems, cloud computing, and network architecture research.
home.cyberDesc: Information security, cryptography, and privacy-preserving technologies.
home.news1Title: CS Professor Wins Prestigious AI Research Award
home.news1Desc: Prof. Anderson recognized for groundbreaking work in neural architecture search.
home.news2Title: Breakthrough in Quantum Computing Published in Nature
home.news2Desc: Research team achieves new milestone in quantum error correction.
home.news3Title: Partnership with Global Tech Leaders Announced
home.news3Desc: New industry collaboration to advance AI and machine learning research.

research.heroTitle: Advancing the Frontiers of Computer Science
research.heroSubtitle: World-class research tackling the most challenging problems in technology and society
research.overviewSub: Our research is organised into six focus areas. Explore each group below for members, themes, and links.
research.groupsSub: Collaborative teams pushing boundaries in specialised areas

research.ctaSub: Collaborate with leading researchers and contribute to groundbreaking discoveries

automata-grammars.title: Theory and Applications of Automata and Grammars
automata-grammars.summary: We work on formal languages, automata theory, and their applications—including descriptional complexity, symmetric difference NFAs, and connections to verification and natural language processing.

software-verification.title: Software Engineering and Verification
software-verification.summary: Research in program verification, testing, and software engineering—including symbolic execution, regular expression matching, and tools for correctness and security.

ml-ai.title: Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence
ml-ai.summary: Advancing artificial intelligence through deep learning, reinforcement learning, and neural architecture search. Applications in vision, NLP, and data analytics.

networks-broadband.title: Broadband and Mobile Networks
networks-broadband.summary: Research on scalable distributed systems, cloud and edge computing, and mobile and broadband network technologies.

robotics-vision.title: Robotics and Computer Vision
robotics-vision.summary: Developing intelligent robots and autonomous systems: perception, path planning, human–robot interaction, and manipulation for real-world applications.

nlp.title: Natural Language Processing
nlp.summary: Work on natural language processing, computational linguistics, and assistive technologies that bridge language and computation.

people.heroSub: Distinguished faculty members and researchers driving innovation in computer science at Stellenbosch University.

institute.title: Institute of Applied Computer Science
institute.intro: Welcome to the homepage of the Institute for Applied Computer Science at the University of Stellenbosch. The institute was founded in 1981 through the initiative of Prof AE Krzesinski and Prof PS Kritzinger.
institute.objectivesIntro: It is our goal to contribute towards the South African software industry by:
institute.objectives:
attracting computer scientists who conduct research in software engineering and who are interested in providing a consultation service to industry
establishing and maintaining international contacts in areas relevant to software development
providing an effective environment for training postgraduate students capable of developing reliable system software
undertaking joint projects with industry in areas such as embedded software development, testing and verification, protocol design and implementation, design of concurrent systems, compilers and design of special purpose languages, device drivers, etc.
developing specialised software for industry
undertaking technical investigations on request
presenting short courses to industry on request
institute.members:
Prof Willem Visser (Director)
Prof Jaco Geldenhuys
Prof AE Krzesinski
institute.addressBag: Private Bag X1, 7602 Matieland, SOUTH AFRICA
institute.pastProjects:
During 1999 – 2014 several courses were presented to industry. The most significant such course series was a four-day programming bootcamp presented 2012–2015 for CapaCITI (an IT initiative of the City of Cape Town).

During 1997 – 1998 a kernel was developed to support protocol stacks on low-powered embedded computing platforms. This kernel was taken over by the South African company SAN People and refined further to support various protocol stacks on embedded devices.

In 1994 the Gneiss microkernel was developed as an improved version of the Hybrid kernel. The Gneiss kernel was used by Spescom-DataVoice to develop a digital voice recording system. This product is marketed locally and internationally and various device drivers were developed for Gneiss to support new device controllers as required.

The Hybrid microkernel was developed during 1990 – 1991. This kernel was designed to support client-server based applications in a distributed environment. The Hybrid kernel was used for developing a distributed application to monitor manufacturing processes in a number of local factories.

In 1988 the Institute was commisioned by the South African company Technology Systems Manufacturing to port Tanenbaum's MINIX system (a Unix-like operating system) to a Data General minicomputer. The goal was to develop local expertise in system programming.

During 1988 – 1993 software was developed for Telkom SA to configure, monitor, optimise and analyse some of their networks.

SNAP, a package to model and analyse stochastic queueing networks, was developed during 1978 – 1985. It was used mainly to predict the performance of IBM mainframe computer systems. The package was sold to UCCEL Corporation in 1985.

study.undergradOverviewIntro: Our undergraduate programme offers a comprehensive education in computer science, blending theoretical knowledge with hands-on experience. Students develop critical thinking, problem-solving, and technical skills essential for success in the modern technology landscape.
study.undergradPracticalSkillsDesc: Hands-on projects, coding challenges, and real-world applications
study.undergradGlobalStandardsDesc: Curriculum aligned with international best practices
study.undergradIndustryReadyDesc: Internships, industry projects, and career preparation
study.undergradRoadmapIntro: A structured 3-year journey from fundamentals to advanced topics
study.undergradHeroSub: Build a strong foundation in computer science and prepare for a successful career in technology. Join a programme that combines theoretical excellence with practical skills.
study.postgradHeroSub: Advance your research and expertise with world-class supervision and facilities.

postgrad.s1Intro: Admission to our programme is based on selection criteria, which includes your academic performance as well as how well your background aligns with the background required for the programme. Capacity is limited and admission is very competitive, so the minimum requirements listed below does not guarantee admission.
postgrad.s1HonoursIntro: To be admitted for Honours in Computer Science, you:
postgrad.s1HonoursBullets:
Need a degree that covers our Computer Science curriculum
Must have obtained an average of at least 65% for your Computer Science modules in your final year (The yearbook lists 60%, but due to high demand, you typically require at least 65%)
Must have a strong mathematical foundation, covering both Algebra and Calculus
Must have at least 32 credits at second-year or third-year level in quantitative modules, including:
Must have practical programming experience
postgrad.s1QuantitativeList:
Mathematics
Applied Mathematics
Physics
Mathematical Statistics
Bioinformatics
Operations Research
GIT242 Digital Photogrammetry
GIT341 Spatial Modeling (note prerequisites)
postgrad.s1HonoursNote: Meeting the minimum requirements means that you will be considered for selection, but does not guarantee admission.
postgrad.s1IndividualIntro: To register for any individual postgraduate module, you need:
postgrad.s1IndividualBullets:
Either a degree in Computer Science
OR
To have fulfilled all requirements to obtain one and receive it at the next scheduled graduation ceremony
The same mathematics, programming, and Computer Science background required for Honours
postgrad.s1MastersBullets:
Requires a degree in Computer Science
Requires an Honours degree
postgrad.s1DoctoralBullets:
Requires a thesis-based Masters degree
Requires a degree that covers the required Computer Science background
postgrad.s2Step1Intro: You need the agreement of a staff member who will supervise your thesis.
postgrad.s2Step1Instructions:
Browse Research pages
Read staff publications
Identify an area of interest
Contact the responsible staff member
Arrange a meeting if possible
Agreement on a topic is not essential at this stage
Agreement on supervision is essential
postgrad.s2Step2Intro: Apply by completing the application forms and uploading required documentation.
postgrad.s2Portals:
Stellenbosch University website → Students → Prospective Postgraduate Students → Application to SU
Science Faculty website → What can I study? → Postgraduate Programmes
Postgraduate Studies website → Application to SU

Masters and Doctoral: End of September (check Science Faculty site)
postgrad.s3PartTimeBullets:
Honours may extend to maximum two consecutive years
Masters may extend to three to four years
Requires discipline and dedication
postgrad.s3HonoursSpecificBullets:
Project must be completed in first or second year
Must complete 6 semester modules
Modules presented during working hours only
No after-hours lectures
postgrad.s3ForeignBullets:
Welcome to apply

16 credit modules = 8 ECTS credits

honours.title: Honours in Computer Science
honours.desc1: The Honours degree is a one-year full-time postgraduate programme that usually follows after the three-year BSc or BCom degree. Over the last forty-five years more than 600 talented students have passed through our programme. It is excellent preparation for pursuing either an MSc degree or a career in industry. This is due in part to the composition of the programme: a mix of core Computer Science theory courses and up-to-date application courses.
honours.desc2: The Honours degree is challenging and hard work and students are required to manage their own time and work more independently than during their undergraduate studies, especially on their year-project. However, we pride ourselves on the fact that our graduates are highly sought after. The degree can have a significant impact on your salary and many companies insist on a four-year degree. Further information, such as application procedures and a FAQ, is available on our page for Prospective postgraduate students.
honours.curriculumIntro:
Full-time design
Part-time maximum two years
Class attendance compulsory
Honours project (32 credits)
Six elective modules (16 credits each)
honours.projectBullets:
Large software construction or research problem
Independent work
Supervised
Does not follow undergraduate semesters
Starts when allocated
Ends with demo and presentation
Students manage own time
honours.electiveBullets:
Six modules required
Block or 15-week structure
Examination week
Finalised each year
Up to two modules from Mathematics or Applied Mathematics (permission required)
Exception modules: Digital Image Processing and Computer Vision
All other external modules require approval
honours.studyPathBullets:
Focus on ML, Data Science, Software Engineering
Or broad range
Staff consultation at start
honours.date1: 2 Feb at 10:00 – Hons Orientation (Room K303, Knowledge Centre, Engineering)
honours.schedulesText: Semester class timetable for 2026: venues TBC
honours.roadmapsIntro: Suggested study directions for Honours students. Select a track to see recommended modules per semester.
honours.roadmapsDisclaimer: Roadmaps are suggested study paths; final module offerings and choices depend on availability and approval.

masters.title: Masters in Computer Science
masters.desc1: Our Masters degree is a two-year programme based on thesis work. The goal is to teach students how to evaluate and conduct world-class research, and become a master in their field. While the work is not required to be original cutting-edge research, it often is. The reading, writing, and critical thinking skills acquired during the Masters degree are also much sought-after in industry, and most of our Masters graduates who do not carry on with a Doctoral degree, go on to have successful careers in the local industry and also abroad.
masters.supervisionBullets:
Must obtain supervisor agreement
Browse Research pages
Review staff publications
Contact staff
Topic agreement not essential before applying
Supervisor agreement essential
Face-to-face meeting recommended
masters.admissionBullets:
Honours degree in Computer Science
OR
Approved equivalent qualification

Additional background/supplementary studies may be required
Case-by-case basis
Further info on Prospective postgraduate students page

doctorate.title: Doctorate in Computer Science
doctorate.desc1: Our PhD in Computer Science is a three-year degree based solely on dissertation work. The goal is to conduct original, cutting-edge research in a particular, specialised field of Computer Science. The student must demonstrate his/her ability to propose, plan, conduct, and publish a research project.
doctorate.supervisionText: You need the agreement of a staff member that will supervise your PhD thesis. Browse through our Research pages and read more about the kind of work we do. You can also look at our staff's publications to get an idea of the kind of topics they are interested in. If you have found an area of our research that interests you, contact the responsible staff member to discuss potential topics. It is not essential to agree on a specific topic before you apply, but it is very important to obtain the staff member's agreement to be your supervisor. If at all possible, make an appointment for a face-to-face meeting.
doctorate.admissionText: The admission requirements for a PhD in Computer Science is a Masters degree in Computer Science or an approved equivalent qualification. Additional background or supplementary studies may be required, as determined by your supervisor(s) on a case-by-case basis. Further information, including application procedures and a FAQ, is available on our page for Prospective postgraduate students.

prospectivePage.title: Postgraduate Studies in Computer Science
prospectivePage.s1Intro: Admission to our programme is based on selection criteria, which includes your academic performance as well as how well your background aligns with the background required for the programme. Capacity is limited and admission is very competitive, so the minimum requirements listed below does not guarantee admission:
prospectivePage.s1HonoursIntro: To be admitted for Honours in Computer Science, you
prospectivePage.s1HonoursBullets:
need a degree that covers our Computer Science curriculum
must have obtained an average of at least 65% for your Computer Science modules in your final year. The yearbook lists the minimum average required to apply as 60%, but due to the number of applications we receive for the BSc Honours in CS programme, you typically require at least 65%.
must have a strong mathematical foundation, covering both Algebra and Calculus
must have at least 32 credits at second-year or third-year level in quantitative modules, which include any module under the following subjects: Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, Physics, Mathematical Statistics, Bioinformatics, and Operations Research and the modules: GIT242 Digital Photogrammetry and GIT341 Spatial Modeling (note their prerequisites)
must have practical programming experience; our Honours degree has a strong focus on programming and it is imperative that you can program to successfully complete the Honours degree
prospectivePage.s1Note: Note, that meeting the minimum requirements means that you will be considered for selection, but does not guarantee admission.
prospectivePage.s1IndividualPara: To register for any individual postgraduate module you need either a degree in Computer Science or must have already fulfilled all the requirements to obtain one and to receive it at the next scheduled graduation ceremony. Furthermore, the same mathematics, programming, and Computer Science background as needed for an Honours in Computer Science is required.
prospectivePage.s1Masters: The entry requirements for a Masters in Computer Science is a degree in Computer Science and an Honours degree
prospectivePage.s1Doctoral: The entry requirements for a Doctoral in Computer Science is a thesis-based Masters degree and a degree that covers the required Computer Science background.
prospectivePage.s2Step1: This step is only for prospective Masters and Doctoral students. You need the agreement of a staff member that will supervise your Masters/Doctoral thesis. Browse through our Research pages and read more about the kind of work we do. You can also look at our staff's publications to get an idea of the kind of topics they are interested in. If you have found an area of our research that interests you, contact the responsible staff member to discuss potential topics. It is not essential to agree on a specific topic at this stage, but it is very important to obtain the staff member's agreement to be your supervisor. If at all possible, make an appointment for a face-to-face meeting.
prospectivePage.s2Step2Intro: This step is for all prospective Honours, Masters, and Doctoral students. Apply by completing the application forms and uploading all the required documentation. The links are available via several pages
prospectivePage.s2Portals:
the Stellenbosch University website; under the Students menu, choose Prospective Postgraduate Students. The links are available under the Application to SU menu.
the Science Faculty website; under the What can I study? drop-down menu, click on Postgraduate Programmes. The links are available on this page as well as under the Application to SU drop-down menu.
the Postgraduate Studies website; the links are available on this page as well as under the Application to SU drop-down menu.
prospectivePage.s2Closing: The closing dates are: for Honours applications: the end of October, but please check the Science Faculty site for the specific date. for Masters and Doctoral applications: the end of September, but please check the Science Faculty site for the specific date.
prospectivePage.s3PartTimePara: The university allows students to enter as part-time students. The degree then extends over more years; the honours degree can be extended to a maximum of two years, which must be consecutive. A part-time Masters degree extends over three to four years. Generally speaking, this is a much harder alternative and requires self-discipline and dedication.
prospectivePage.s3HonoursNoteTitle: Honours students should take note of the following:
prospectivePage.s3HonoursNoteBullets:
The project has to be completed within either the first or the second year
You have to complete 6 semester-modules in total, but you can choose which ones to complete in which year
All of our modules are presented during working hours, and there is no option at the moment to attend lectures after-hours. If you have a full-time job, you will have to arrange with your employer to attend lectures.
prospectivePage.s3ForeignPara: We also welcome applications from foreign students. In addition to the application steps mentioned above, you should also contact the university's Postgraduate Office for administrative details about studying at Stellenbosch. Stellenbosch University has many partnership agreements with foreign universities, making it easy to arrange student exchanges. Our 16 credit modules are equivalent to 8 ECTS credits, and all of the modules are presented in English.
prospectivePage.s4Title: What about the costs and financial support?
prospectivePage.s4Para1: Computer Science does not offer any direct support for students, but the university as a whole does, and of course there are many external bursaries available. The university's portal for prospective students is a good source of information about such bursaries and up-to-date details about tuition fees. (International students should also have a look at the "Student fees and funding » Funding" section of the Postgraduate Office website.)
prospectivePage.s4Para2: Most of our undergraduate modules require teaching assistants and we expect students who have completed them to get involved with at least one such module. While it will not provide enough income to support your studies, these positions can provide some supplemental income. But more than this: becoming a teaching assistant is not only a wonderful way to help the next generation of Computer Science students with their studies, but also a great opportunity to consolidate your own knowledge!
prospectivePage.s4Para3: Some supervisors also have research funds available to support Masters or Doctoral students, but once again it may not necessarily provide enough income to cover all your expenses. Note that you cannot rely on this and must talk directly to the supervisor about this option.
prospectivePage.s5Title: What are the prerequisites for individual Postgraduate modules?
prospectivePage.s5AllIntro: All honours modules presented by Computer Science require:
prospectivePage.s5AllBullets:
the four core third-year Computer Science modules,
Mathematics and Probability Theory & Statistics (Applied Mathematics) up to first year, and
preferably at least one of Mathematics or Applied Mathematics up to second year.
prospectivePage.s5DigitalBullets: a working knowledge of Fourier Analysis; this is covered in Applied Maths 364.
prospectivePage.s5VisionBullets: linear algebra; this is covered in Applied Mathematics 214 and Mathematics 214.
